Award.AbstractNarration: Larsen<br/>DMS-0807825<br/><br/> The investigator develops and studies models for the<br/>evolution of elastic damage (i.e., regions of weakened elastic<br/>properties) and fracture. Difficulties come from, among other<br/>things, the irreversibility of these phenomena, and the fact that<br/>existing models are essentially variational (static). The<br/>general strategy is to first develop quasi-static models that are<br/>consistent with these variational principles, and prove existence<br/>and approximation results. Next, the goal is to extend these<br/>results to the fully dynamic setting. The first step has been<br/>essentially completed for damage and brittle fracture, and the<br/>investigator works on developing corresponding methods for<br/>cohesive fracture. Dynamic models and their analysis are major<br/>open problems for all these phenomena, and are the main focus of<br/>this project.<br/><br/> Material damage and fracture prediction are of fundamental<br/>importance in the areas of materials and manufacturing, civil<br/>infrastructure, etc., yet in the most physically realistic<br/>setting (dynamics) there is no sound mathematical footing, making<br/>engineering models largely ad hoc. The investigator works on<br/>developing this mathematical support, as well as creating and<br/>rigorously justifying algorithms for computing approximate<br/>solutions. The project includes training mathematics Ph.D.<br/>students through work on important interdisciplinary problems.<br/>
